member.name: M:PHP.Core.AssemblyLoader.LoadScriptLibrary(System.String,System.Uri,System.String)
member.summary: Loads assembly as script library, adding all scripts it contains into script library database.
member.param: Long assembly name (see ) or a null reference.
Assembly file absolute URI or a null reference.

Root offset of the script library. All scripts will be loaded with this offset. Strict behavior forbids conflicts between scriptLibrary and filesystem, all conflicts will be reported as errors. This is used in the runtime (dynamic include), compiler currently ignores filesystem.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.AssemblyLoader.LoadScriptLibrary(System.Reflection.Assembly,System.String)
member.summary: Loads assembly as script library, adding all scripts it contains into script library database.
member.param: Script assembly that is to be loaded.

Root offset of the script library. All scripts will be loaded with this offset. Strict behavior forbids conflicts between scriptLibrary and filesystem, all conflicts will be reported as errors. This is used in the runtime (dynamic include), compiler currently ignores filesystem.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.AllowReturnValueOverrideAttribute
member.summary: Interface method marked by this attribute can be implemented without adhering to its return type.
member.remarks: An interface method returning by reference (&) that is decorated by this attribute can be implemented by a method that does not return by reference. Attribute is used by .

member.name: T:PHP.Core.AllowParametersOverrideAttribute
member.summary: Interface method marked by this attribute can be implemented without adhering to its parameters.
member.remarks: Attribute is used by .

member.name: T:PHP.Core.PhpPublicFieldAttribute
member.summary: PHP allows increasing visibility of fields that are declared as protected in ancestor class. A class that increases the visibility declares no field but is marked with that attribute.
member.remarks: Attribute is used by .

member.name: T:PHP.Core.CodeDom.Helper
member.summary: Conntains helper members for PHP-to-CodeDOM translator
member.remarks: These members may appear in CodeDOM which originates from user-typed PHP code. It is because PHP-to-CodeDOM translator is not designed to be universal. It is primary designed to translate CodeDOM-to-PHP-generator-generated code back to PHP and it supports only very few PHP spoecialities. These helper members usually stands for somethink that cannot be repserented in CodeDOM but in PHP can. The aim of these members is NOT to substitute PHP behavior and implement it for CodeDOM. The aim of these members is to translate CodeDOM-unsupported feature from PHP to CodeDOM somehow. In the future it may allow CodeDOM-to-PHP translator to translate such construct to PHP to the same code that have generated it. In order to avoid usage of these members by users members are hidden and obsolete.

member.returns: Translated expression
member.remarks: If does not contain any associative item (it is item with != null) array initialization is translated inline like C# object[] = new object[]{item1,item2,item3}. This does not require . If there is any associative item in the list, expression is translated using as creation of new variable of type and then filled using for non-associative items and for associative ones. In this case function returns refernce to newly created variable.

member.summary: Notices the Analyzer that unreachable code has been entered

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Analyzer.LeaveUnreachableCode
member.summary: Notices the Analyzer that unreachable code has been leaved
member.remarks: This method is called only from because unreachable code ends at the end of conditional block and from because unreachable declarations in global code are valid.

The name of routine to be resolved.

The routine where the searched routine is being called. Can be null.

True if the searched routine is called statically - if it uses static method call syntax. This affects the __call or __callStatic method lookup. It affects also the error reporting, where for instance method calls, the bad visibility error is ignored and falls back to return .

Will determine if __call or __callStatic magic methods were found instead.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.AST.ValueAssignEx.Analyze(PHP.Core.Analyzer,PHP.Core.AST.ExInfoFromParent)

member.name: M:PHP.Core.AST.ValueAssignEx.Emit(PHP.Core.CodeGenerator)
member.summary: Emits assignment.
member.remarks:
Pattern: a op= b
PREPARE a (prepared) LOAD a (prepared,a) LOAD b (prepared,a,b) OP (prepared,result) *DUP (prepared,result,result) *STORE tmp (prepared,result) must be this stack here! STORE a () *LOAD tmp (result)
* only if the resulting value needs to be propagated to the right
Note: There is a possible improvement: some store operations (SetVariable) may return the value set which would replace DUP and second temp op.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.AST.ValueAssignEx.EmitSourceValRead(PHP.Core.CodeGenerator)
member.summary: Emits the RHS of assignment.
member.returns: of the RHS.

member.summary: A holder of a temporary local variable which is used to obtain address of a variable stored in runtime variables table when methods from expecting a ref argument are invoked.

This holder does not take place in optimalized user functions and methods of user classes as the address of a variable shoul be obtained directly (variables are defined as locals).

member.name: M:PHP.Core.AST.SimpleVarUse.LoadTabledVariableAddress(PHP.Core.CodeGenerator)

member.remarks: This method is used only in non-optimized user functions and global code. Specified local variable is obtained from current by and stored to for later use. Once the local become useless, should be called.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.ChainBuilder.Chain.LoadAddressOfFunctionReturnValue
member.summary:
Gets or sets a flag indicating whether to force the FunctionCall to place the address of return value in the evaluation stack. The address is consumed by an operator. E.g.:
Chain: $z =& $x->f()->y; AST: [RAE] / | [DVU] | | [DVU] +- member of -- [DFC] +- member of -- [DVU]
Property set since requires the parameter (DFC) to be an address.

member.remarks: Causes that the next calling (or calling that has been suspend) on this assembly will imediately return the just built (if success was true) or null (if succes was false).

member.name: T:PHP.Core.WebCompilationContext

member.name: M:PHP.Core.WebCompilationContext.GetAssemblyCodedName(PHP.Core.PhpSourceFile,PHP.Core.CompilerConfiguration)
member.summary: Translates a source path to an assembly coded name.
member.returns: The code name consisting of significant configuration hashcode and source path relative to the application source root. Format of the name: {relativized path}(~{level_count})?#{config hash}# Backslashes and colons are replaced with underscores, underscores are doubled.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.WebCompilationContext.GetAssemblyFullName(PHP.Core.PhpSourceFile)
member.summary: Gets a full name of an assembly in which a specified source script is compiled.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.WebServerCompilerManager
member.summary: Manager for a compiling a web aplication by multiple compilers in parallel. Designed to be able to work in remote appdomain, yet this feature is currently not utilized.

remarks.para:
Cache maps coded assembly names to assembly file paths. In addition, a set of dependencies is added to each cache item. These dependencies comprises of
source script file
cache items representing included script
Cache item key should be determined by script source path which is the only information the compiler provides to the manager. Thus, it equals to the coded name of the assembly got by .
Assembly name is composed from request timestamp and coded assembly name. Assembly file name equals to the assembly name suffixed with .dll extension. is used to build assemblies up.

member.name: F:PHP.Core.WebServerCompilerManager.AttemptsToGetCompiledAssembly
member.summary: The number of attepts which are made to get an assembly which is being compiled by another thread before this thread starts its own compilaation. Each attempt is limited in time by .

member.name: M:PHP.Core.WebServerCompilerManager.GetCompiledScript(PHP.Core.PhpSourceFile,PHP.Core.RequestContext)
member.summary:
Retrives a compiled script.
The method check scripts in following order: 1. Script Library database. 2. Modified source file on the file system. 3. Unmodified source file in precompiled WebPages.dll.
member.param: The current HTTP context. Can be null in case of desktop app.
member.returns: The script type or a null reference on failure.
member.remarks: The method do check the script library database.

member.returns: The compiled script type.

member.summary: Decide whether allow loading built assemblies into memory. This would disallows proper debugging.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.WebServerCompilerManager.CacheEntry
member.summary: Structure that contains loaded scripts. The cache is built while application is running and is lost when the AppDomain is reloaded.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.WebServerCompilerManager.CacheEntry.Includers
member.summary: Collection of scripts that include this script - if the item is invalidated all includers must be invalidated too

member.name: P:PHP.Core.WebServerCompilerManager.CacheEntry.Includees
member.summary: Collection of included scripts - after loading (from temp files or when application starts) we need to check whether all included files are up-to-date

member.name: P:PHP.Core.WebServerCompilerManager.CacheEntry.FileTimeChecked
member.summary:
Whether the source file time-stamp has been checked. Precompiled source files need to be checked because thay may have been modified prior to the start of the watcher. Although it would be possible to do so during assembly load, it could make the load quite slow and files that are even not used may be checked unnecessarily. Therefore the check is done lazily.
Source files compiled while the watcher is active needn't to be checked.

member.summary: Drops the configuration associated with the current thread and loads a new one. Doesn't reload XML data from file (cached configuration records are reused). The libraries listed in the classLibrary section are therefore not loaded into the context.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Convert.IsNumber(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int64@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Converts a string to integer value and double value and decides whether it represents a number as a whole.
member.param: Maximum zero-based index within given to be proccessed. Must be greater than or equal 0 and less than or equal to string length.
A position where to start parsing.
Returns a position where long-integer-parsing ended (the first character not included in the resulting double value).
Returns a position where double-parsing ended (the first character not included in the resulting double value).
Result of the conversion to integer.
Result of the conversion to long integer.
Result of the conversion to double.
member.returns:
Information about parsed number including its type, which is the narrowest one that fits. E.g. IsNumber("10 xyz", ...) includes NumberInfo.Integer, IsNumber("10000000000000 xyz", ...) includes NumberInfo.LongInteger, IsNumber("10.9 xyz", ...) includes NumberInfo.Double, IsNumber("10.9", ...) includes NumberInfo.IsNumber and NumberInfo.Double.
The return value always includes one of NumberInfo.Integer, NumberInfo.LongInteger, NumberInfo.Double and never NumberInfo.Unconvertible (as each string is convertible to a number).

member.remarks: Size may contain either a number of bytes or number of kilo/mega/giga bytes with suffix "K"/"M"/"G". The first non-white-space character from the end of the string is taken as the suffix. All numbers may be "PHP numbers", i.e. only a prefix containing an integer is taken. member.summary: Returns a list of overloads that can be called with the given argument count on the stack.
member.remarks: Vararg overloads are at the end of the returned list and are sorted, so that more general overloads are at the end of the list (for example: params object[] is more general than int,params object[]).

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Emit.ClrOverloadBuilder.GetVarArgOverloads(System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns overloads including the "params" option
member.remarks: Returned overloads are sorted, so that more general overloads are at the end of the list (for example: params object[] is more general than int,params object[]).

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Emit.ClrOverloadBuilder.SortVarArgOverloads(System.Collections.Generic.List{PHP.Core.Reflection.ClrMethod.Overload},System.Int32)
member.summary:
This function sorts vararg overloads so that more general overloads are at the end. The only difference to algorithm used for sorting overloads during initialization is that we need overloads with MORE parameters first (because this means we have some more specific type requirements declared by mandatory parameters).
Assumes that input is sorted only the blocks with same parameter count needs to be reversed.
We need to sort parameters like this to prevent conversions to supertypes (like object[]), becausethis kind of conversion is treated as ImplExactMatch.
member.param: Vararg overloads start at this index
member.remarks: Sorting should be for example: #parameters = 2 + 1: int, string, [params] int[] int, string, [params] object[] #parameters = 1 + 1: int, [params] object[] #parameters = 0 + 1: [params] int[] [params] object[]

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Emit.ILEmitter.MarkFeature(System.Object)
member.summary: Marks the Microsoft intermediate language (MSIL) stream's current position as a distinguished control flow point related to a "feature".

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Emit.ILEmitter.IsFeatureControlFlowPrecedent(System.Object)
member.summary: Determines whether the Microsoft intermediate language (MSIL) stream's current position is unconditionally preceded by a previously marked "feature".
member.param: The feature ID passed earlier to (non-null).
member.returns: null if current position surely uncoditionally follows the position identified by , false otherwise.

remarks.para: This method returns null if it is possible to prove that whenever IL execution reaches current position, it has already reached the position marked by ().

These are the sufficient conditions used by this implementation (inclusive or):
All branch instructions before the feature point have their targets before the feature point, and there is no instruction between the feature point and current position.
There is no branch target between the feature point and current position that is referenced before the feature point or left open (unforgotten) at current positionn and there is no instruction between the feature point and current position.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Emit.OverloadsBuilder.EmitMandatoryArgumentLoad(System.Int32,System.Reflection.ParameterInfo)
member.summary: Emits load of a specified mandatory argument and appropriate conversions on it. Leaves the result on the evaluation stack so it can be later passed as an argument to a method.
member.param: The index of the parameter counted from zero.
member.remarks: Arguments passed by object reference (ref/out) are handled in the manner of in/out semantics. If the argument is passed by object reference a holder local variable of the smae type is created. A reference passed as the actual argument is peeked from PHP stack, converted to the target type by and stored in the holder. Then the holder's address is passed to the overload. On the return from the overload each holder's value is stored back to the actual argument by . In order to do so holder local variable builders and the local variables builders storing the actual argument are added to and , respectively, by this method.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Emit.OverloadsBuilder.EmitReferencesLoad
member.summary: Emits code loading values stored in holder variables into respective references.

member.param: The type of the formal argument. Shouldn't be .
The type of the formal argument or its value if it is a literal.

In case of IIS Classic Mode, headers must be cached and flushed in 'PreSendRequestHeaders' event, because .NET doesn't allow this behavior. In case of IIS Integrated Pipeline, request headers can be accessed (set/modified/removed) within HttpRequest object in any time.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.PhpStream
member.summary: Abstraction of streaming behavior for PHP. PhpStreams are opened by StreamWrappers on a call to fopen().
Abstraction of streaming behavior for PHP. PhpStreams are opened by StreamWrappers on a call to fopen().

remarks.para: PhpStream is a descendant of PhpResource, it contains a StreamContext (may be empty) and two ordered lists of StreamFilters (input and output filters). PhpStream may be cast to a .NET stream (using its RawStream property).

Various stream types are defined by overriding the Raw* methods that provide direct access to the underlying physical stream. Corresponding public methods encapsulate these accessors with buffering and filtering. Raw stream access is performed at the byte[] level. ClassLibrary functions may use either the Read/WriteBytes or Read/WriteString depending on the nature of the PHP function. Data are converted using the as necessary.

When reading from a stream, the stream data is read in binary format in chunks of predefined size (8kB). Stream filters (if any) are then applied in a cascade to the whole block. Filtered blocks are stored in a of either strings or PhpBytes depending on the last filter output (note that after filtering not all blocks have necessarily the original chunk size; when appending a filter to the filter-chain all the buffered data is passed through this one too). The input queue is being filled until the required data length is available. The property holds the index into the first chunk of data. When this chunk is entirely consumed it is dequeued.

Writing to a stream is buffered too (unless it is disabled using stream_set_write_buffer). When the data passes through the filter-chain it is appended to the write buffer (using the property). When the write buffer is full it is flushed to the underlying stream.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpStream.CheckAccess(System.String,PHP.Core.CheckAccessMode,PHP.Core.CheckAccessOptions)
member.summary: Performs all checks on a path passed to a PHP function.

remarks.para: This method performs a check similar to safe_mode.c: php_checkuid_ex() together with open_basedir check.

The may be one of the following:
A relative path. The path is resolved regarding the include_path too if required and checking continues as in the next case.
An absolute path. The file or directory is checked for existence and for access permissions1 according to the given .
1 Regarding the open_basedir configuration option. File access permissions are checked at the time of file manipulation (opening, copying etc.).

member.param: A resolved path. Must be an absolute path to a local file.
member.returns: true if the function may continue with file access, falseto fail.
member.exception: If the file can not be accessed and the is not set.

member.summary: Reads a block of data from the stream up to characters or up to EOLN if is negative.
member.remarks: ReadData first looks for data into the . While is not satisfied, new data from the underlying stream are processed. The data is buffered as either or but consistently. The type of the first buffer thus specifies the return type.
member.param: The number of bytes to return, when set to -1 reading carries on up to EOLN or EOF.
If true, the buffers are first searched for \n.
member.returns: A or containing the data as returned from the last stream filter or null in case of an error or EOF.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpStream.Tell
member.summary: Gets the current position in the stream.

remarks.newpara: The problem with tell() in PHP is that although the write offset is calculated in the raw byte stream (just before buffering) the read one is calculated in the filtered string buffers.

In other words the value returned by tell() for output streams is the real position in the raw stream but may differ from the number of characters written. On the other hand the value returned for input streams corresponds with the number of characters retreived but not with the position in the raw stream. It is important to remember that seeking on a filtered stream (such as a file opened with a "rt" mode) has undefined behavior.

member.returns: The position in the filtered or raw stream depending on last read or write access type respectively or -1 if the stream does not support seeking.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.PhpStream.IsReadBuffered
member.summary: Gets or sets the read fragmentation behavior.

remarks.para: Network and console input streams return immediately after a nonempty data is read from the underlying stream. Buffered streams try to fill the whole given buffer while the underlying stream is providing data to satisfy the caller-specified length or .
Still the input buffer may contain valid data even for unbuffered streams. This may happen for example when a fgets has to return unconsumed data (following the first EOL) back to the stream.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.PhpStream.IsWriteBuffered
member.summary: Gets the write fragmentation behavior.
member.remarks: When the write is not buffered then all the fwrite calls pass the data immediately to the underlying stream.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.Reflection.DMember.DeclaringType
member.summary: Declaring type of the member.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.Reflection.DMember.IsIdentityDefinite
member.summary:
Whether the analyzer can be sure about the identity of the member. That is for types, whether the analyzer can refer to the modifiers, generic parameters and the members declared directly by the type (inherited members needn't to be definite).
For functions, whether the analyzer can refer to the signature of the function.
Class constants, fields, and methods are identity definite iff they are known (identity definiteness of the type's member is relative to the declaring type). The analyzer can refer to the modifiers and signatures of the identity definite methods.
Constructed types are identity definite iff the generic type is identity definite as the members of the constructed types are same as ones of the generic types and only the type parameter substitution needn't to be known.
Generic parameters are not identity definite as their substitute is unknown.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.Reflection.DMember.IsDefinite
member.summary: Whether the analyzer and code generator can be sure about the entire structure of the member, i.e. whether the member is identity definite and all members that influences its structure (e.g. all base types) are definite.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Execution.EscapeCommand(System.String)
member.summary: Escape shell metacharacters in a specified shell command.
member.para: On Windows platform, each occurance of a character that might be used to trick a shell command is replaced with space. These characters are ", ', #, &, ;, `, |, *, ?, ~, <, >, ^, (, ), [, ], {, }, $, \, \u000A, \u00FF, %.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Execution.MakeCommandSafe(System.String@)
member.summary: Makes command safe in similar way PHP does.
member.returns: Safe command.
member.remarks: If safe mode is enabled, command is split by the first space into target path and arguments (optionally) components. The target path must not contain '..' substring. A file name is extracted from the target path and combined with . The resulting path is checked for invalid path characters (Phalanger specific). Finally, arguments are escaped by and appended to the path. If safe mode is disabled, the command remains unchanged.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.IExternals
member.summary: This is the main interface between PHP.NET Core and ExtManager.

remarks.para: This interface is implemented by RemoteDispatcher class in php4ts.dll (project ExtSupport). Most of these methods also have their static counterparts in (stubs).

For extensions configured as "isolated", serves as a remote interface for interprocess communication. For extensions configured as "collocated", an instance of RemoteDispatcher implementing is created in the current .

member.name: M:PHP.Core.IExternals.GetFunctionProxy(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Get external function proxy object. The object is used for invocation specified function/method.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.IExternals.InvokeFunction(System.String,System.String,System.Object[]@,System.Int32[],System.String)
member.summary: Invokes an external function.
member.param: The name of the extension where the function is defined (without trailing '.DLL').
Indexes into the marking parameters that should be passed by reference, and optionally terminated with -1 which means that from the last marked parameter on, everything should be passed by reference.
member.returns: The return value of the function.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.IExternals.InvokeMethod(System.String,System.String,System.String,PHP.Core.PhpObject@,System.Object[]@,System.Int32[],System.String)
member.summary: Invokes an external method.
member.param: The name of the extension where the method is defined (without trailing '.DLL').
The name of the declaring class.
The instance on which the method is to be invoked.
Indexes into the marking parameters that should be passed by reference, and optionally terminated with -1 which means that from the last marked parameter on, everything should be passed by reference.
member.returns: The return value of the method.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.IExternals.BindParameter(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a proxy of a variable (zval) that lives in ExtManager as one of the last function/method invocation parameters.
member.returns: A implementing the interface, or null if the proxy could not be created.
member.remarks:
The reason for returning null include:
no external function/method invocation has yet been performed by the ExtManager
the is greater or equal to the number of parameters of the last invocation
the external function/method did not increment the corresponding zval's reference counter, thus the zval has been released

member.name: M:PHP.Core.IExternals.GetStreamWrapper(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a proxy of a stream wrapper that lives in ExtManager.
member.param: The scheme portion of an URL that a wrapper is requested for.
member.returns: A implementing the interface, or null if there is no wrapper for the given .
member.remarks: Since PHP stream wrappers are stateless, the returned MBRO's lifetime should be limited only to the lifetime of the corresponding ExtManager instance.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.IExternals.GetStreamWrapperSchemes
member.summary: Returns an of schemes of all available external stream wrappers.
member.returns: The of schemes (for example { "ftp", "http" }).

member.name: M:PHP.Core.IExternals.GetStartupErrors
member.summary: Returns an of error messages.
member.returns: An of strings - error messages of errors that occured during ExtManager(s) startup.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.IExternals.PhpInfo

member.name: M:PHP.Core.IExternals.GetInstanceUrl(System.String,PHP.Core.ApplicationConfiguration,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,PHP.Core.ExtensionLibraryDescriptor})
member.summary: Returns the private URL of the current ExtManager.
member.param: The well-known URL through which this method is called.
member.returns: The instance (private) URL.
member.remarks: Each ExtManager creates two channels. One of them is a channel with a well-known section name. The other one has a generated unique section name. RemoteDispatcher can be called through both of them. However, if you use the well-known one, you might be talking to different instances of ExtManager every time you make a call. This is alright when there is no request context. If you are operating in a request context, all calls must be served by the same instance of ExtManager. Therefore, you should first call to obtain a URL through which you then connect to RemoteDispatcher again. But with this connection, you can be sure that as long as your request is active, "your" ExtManager doesn't terminate (unless something terrible happens, of course). ExtManager can be gracefully terminated by calling . Usually you will do this after you have changed configuration.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.RequestCookie
member.summary: A cookie associated with threads that make remote calls.

remarks.para: One instance of RequestCookie is associated with each thread that makes remote calls to isolated external modules (extensions). Its purpose is to terminate the request as soon as it is clear that this thread won't make any more remote calls. This happens basically at the moment of RequestCookie finalization. Terminating ExtManager's requests as soon as possible is quite important because external modules might hold scarce unmanaged resources like database connections.

If external functions are used during processing of a page request and nothing goes terribly wrong, ExtManager's requests are terminated by calling . However, if external functions are used through managed wrappers by an arbitrary .NET program, will not be called. If this situation occurs, a terminator 'delegate' is invoked during 's finalization (terminator 'delegate' is not really a but rather the method, and is set by ExtManager to its method that terminates the request).
Nevertheless, GC does not guarantee that is ever called. If this happens, the request will simply time out. is registered as a lifetime sponsor for the associated Request instance.

Last note: if no external function is called during processing a page, there is not overhead at all. Specifically, no remote calls are made. It is the same for the situation when no external function is called from an arbitrary .NET program that references some managed wrappers - there is no overhead at all.

member.returns: Return value of the function.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.AutoGlobals
member.summary: Declares auto-global variables stored in the script context.

summary.para: If server context is available contains server variables ($_SERVER). Moreover, it contains PHP_SELF - a virtual path to the executing script and if is set it contains also argv (an array containing a query string as its one and only element) and argc which is set to zero.
If server context is not available contains empty array (unlike PHP which does fill it with and then adds some empty items).

list.item: $_FILES[{var_name}]['name'] - The original name of the file on the client machine.
$_FILES[{var_name}]['type'] - The mime type of the file, if the browser provided this information. An example would be "image/gif".
$_FILES[{var_name}]['size'] - The size, in bytes, of the uploaded file.
$_FILES[{var_name}]['tmp_name'] - The temporary filename of the file in which the uploaded file was stored on the server.
$_FILES[{var_name}]['error'] - The error code associated with this file upload.

member.remarks: Stably sorts a portion of a list of s.
member.param: The comparer used to sort elements.

The first element in the portion.
The element following the last element of the portion before a call is made.
The element which will be set as successor of the last element of the list.
member.returns: The sorted portion. Reference to the first element of unidirectional list.

remarks.para: The list's first element is referenced by the parameter.
The portion is elements long. A reference to an element which has immediately followed the last element of the sorted portion before the method had been called will be returned in the .

The portion is sorted and the resulting unidirectional list is returned. Elements are joined only in one direction - fields of elements are connected. fields have to be connected subsequently as well as the head of the list.
The sort is stable, key-value associations are preserved as well as references.

H H H | | | ~o~o~o~ | | | ~ = Prev (right to left), cyclic without a head (necessary) ~o~o~o~ - = Next (top to bottom), cyclic with a head (not necessary) | | |

member.name: T:PHP.Core.OrderedHashtable`1.Enumerator
member.summary: Unbreakable enumerator which iterates through a hashtable in the order in which elements were added.

remarks.para: If the enumerator reaches a head of a list it stops enumeration ( returns false) and has to be restarted in order to enumerate the list again from the beginning. Before it is done so both Value and Key properties return a reference to internal singleton which cannot be accessed except for checinkg its type. Note, a key of an entry can never be a null reference.

Items can be deleted from an underlying Ordered Hashtable during an enumeration. When an item is removed is is immediately deleted from the underlying hashtable and remains only connected to the list to allow enumeration continuation. Since deleted items are skipped by all enumerator's operations (, , ...) such an item cannot be accessed once it is deleted.
Thanks to above two properties there is no exception thrown by this enumerator.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.PhpHashtable.RecursiveEnumerator
member.summary: Recursively enumerates .

remarks.para: Enumerator starts enumeration with a specified in its constructor and enumerates its items by instance of retrieved via . This enumerator is supposed to be unbreakable. If an enumerated item value is (or and its is and property is true) then this item is returned by Current and Entry like any other item but the enumerator continues with enumeration of that item when it is moved by . The of recursion is increased and the previous hashtable is pushed in the internal stack. When enumerator finishes the enumeration of the current level hashtable and the level of recursion is not zero it pops hashtable stored in the stack and continues with enumeration on the item immediately following the item which caused the recursion.

Before the level of recursion is raised enumerator checks whether the next level hashtable was not already visited by any recursive enumerator. If that is the case such hashtable is skipped to prevent infinite recursion. Note, that you should not use more than one on the same . This is not checked automatically but it is left to the user to avoid such usage. One can check whether the current item will cause a recursion by inspecting property.
Enumerator is unbreakable (i.e. enumerated hashtables may be changed while enumerating them).

member.name: T:PHP.Core.Operators
member.summary: Operators used by PHP language.
member.remarks:
The compiler keeps track of whether or not a variable is a reference but doesn't do so in the case of a property or an array item. Moreover, a variable cannot be null. Thus
an operator returning an item of an array or a property of an object dereferences return value itself,
operands of type should not be of type ,
an operator returning a should never return a null reference.
In the following tables p, q are references while x, y, z, u, v are not (if a corresponding variable is a then is used instead). The context is the current and the type is the current as described in the following paragraph.
Operators working on have a parameter named caller. When such an operator is used in a PHP function, null is supplied. When the operator is used in a PHP method, the of the class this method belongs to is supplied. Finally, when the operator is used in a script's Main() method, the that comes as one of Main()'s parameters is supplied.
Simple operatorsImplementation
x && y(x) && (y)
x || y(x) || (y)
x xor y(x) xor (y)
!x!(x);
x & y(x,y,BitOp.)
x | y(x,y,BitOp.)
x ^ y(x,y,BitOp.)
~x(x)
x++x = (x)
x--x = (x)
x + y(x,y)
x - y(x,y)
x * y(x,y)
x / y(x,y)
x % y(x,y)
x << y(x,y)
x >> y(x,y)
-x(x)
+x(x)
x . y(x,y)
a . ... . z(new object[] {a,...,z})
x == yPhpComparer.Default.(x,y)
x != y!PhpComparer.Default.(x,y)
x === y(x,y)
x !== y!(x,y)
x <= yPhpComparer.Default.(x,y) <= 0
x >= yPhpComparer.Default.(x,y) >= 0
x < yPhpComparer.Default.(x,y) < 0
x > yPhpComparer.Default.(x,y) > 0
x = yx = PhpVariable.(y,CopyReason.);
p =& qp = q
isset(x)x != null1
unset(x)x = null
unset(p)p.value = null
({int|integer})x(x)
({bool|boolean})x(x)
({float|real|double})x(x)
(string)x(x)
(array)x(x)
(object)x(x,context)
(unset)xnull
`x`Execution.(x)
@scontext.(); s; context.();
new A("A",type_handle,context)
c?s:tif (c) {s} else {t};
clone(x)(x)
x instanceOf A(x,"A",type_handle,context)
1 isset doesn't distinguish between a null and uninitialized variable
Item and property operators2Implementation
x[] = z(PhpVariable.(z,CopyReason.),ref x)
x[] =& p(p,ref x)
p =& x[](p = new PhpReference(),ref x)
x[y](x,y,false)
x[y] = z(y,PhpVariable.(z,CopyReason.),ref x)
x[y] =& p(y,p,ref x)
p =& x[y]p = (y,ref x)
isset(x[])error - operator [] without key cannot be used for reading
isset(x[y])(x,y,true)!=null
unset(x[y])(x,y)
x->y(x,y,type_handle,false)
x->y = z(z,ref x,y,PhpVariable.(y,CopyReason.),type_handle,context)
x->y =& p(p,ref x,y,type_handle,context)3
p =& x->y(ref x,y,type_handle,context)
isset(x->y)(x,y,type_handle,true)
unset(x->y)(x,y,type_handle)
A::$y("A",y,type_handle,context,false)
A::$y = z("A",PhpVariable.(y,CopyReason.),type_handle,context)
A::$y =& p("A",y,p,type_handle,context)
p =& A::$y("A",y,type_handle,context)
isset(A::$y)("A",y,type_handle,context,true)
unset(A::$y)("A",y,type_handle,context)4
A::x("A",x,type_handle,context)
2 Note, operator x{y} is implemented in the same way as x[y].
3 Note, there is no -Ref suffix here.
4 It is an error to unset static property.
Function and method callsImplementation
x->f(args)(x,"f",type_handle)
A::f(args)("A","f",type_handle)
$f(args)PhpFunction.("f",context)
Before a function or a method is called arguments are pushed context. by . Operators stated in the table above are used only if the function/method being called is not known at the compile time. Otherwise, direct call to the function/method is emitted.
Chained operators
Several patterns are possible:
x = chain - chain is read,
chain = y - chain is written,
x =& chain - chain is written,
chain =& y - chain is written,
where chain is a sequence of item and/or member operators [u], [], {u}, ->v at least 2 operators long. The first operator can also be a function call operator or a static property access operator. The last operator can be method call operator. As of PHP 5 method call operator () can be also chained and a static method call can be the first operation in the chain.
It's suitable to decompose a chain into three parts for its compilation.
Possible occurences of operators in the chain:
Chain is read Chain is written
first x[y], x{y}, x->y, x->f(), f(), A::$x, A::f() x[], x[y], x{y}, x->y, x->f(), f(), A::$x, A::f()
middle x[y], x{y}, x->y, x->f() x[], x[y], x{y}, x->y, x->f()
last x[y], x{y}, x->y, x->f() x[], x[y], x{y}, x->y
Example 1: a[k1][k2]->k3->k4 Example 2: a[k1][]->k2->k3[k4] Example 3: A::$x[k1]->f(arg)->x Example 4: g()->x->h()
If a chain is read and if any item/property listed doesn't exist in the appropriate array/object the result will be a null reference. In the case the chain is written and some item or property should be an array (bacause it is followed by [] or {} operator in the chain) but it is empty in the terms of then such item/property is replaced by a new empty array. If some item or property should be a PHP object (bacause it is followed by -> operator in the chain) but it is empty in the terms of then such item/property is replaced by a new instance of . However, a static property is not created if doesn't exist (an error is reported).
Chain reading:
It is a fatal error if there is a [] operator without a key in a chain which is read. If the chain doesn't contain any such operator it is compiled as a sequence of , , operators and function and method calls.
The chain from the first example will be compiled as follows (x = a[k1][k2]->k3->k4):
x = PhpVariable.Copy( GetProperty( GetProperty( GetItem( GetItem(a,k1,false),k2,false),k3,type_handle,false),k4,type_handle,false),CopyReason.Assigned);
The chain in the fourth example stated above is compiled as follows (x = g()->x->h(), assuming declarations function g() {...} and function h() {...} for example):
x = PhpVariable.Copy( Operators.InvokeMethod( Operators.GetProperty( g(),"x",type_handle),"h",type_handle),CopyReason.Assigned);
Chain writing:
Chain which is written and contains function/method calls can be divided into subchains which doesn't contain function calls in the middle. Subchaines are compiled separately as described below. Because subchains and chains not containing function/method calls are compiled in the same way, only the compilation of chains is described below.
Lets follow the chain decomposition:
The first operator in the chain ensures that a variable or a static property which it is applied on is an array or an object. It is implemented by , , or .
The next operators up to the last but one ensures that an item or a property on which it is used is an array or an object and is implemented by , , , or .
The last operator sets or gets the resulting value of the chain. It is implemented by , , , , , , , by a function/method call. These methods takes an argument of a particular type which is determined by the previous operator.
Each "Ensure" operator returns the requested item/property (possibly creates a new one if not exists or the existing is empty in the terms of ). This returned value is passed to the next operator in the chain. PhpArray. operator always adds a new item to an array on which is applied. The result passed to the next is the item added. The pattern is array.Add({result} = new PhpArray());
The chain in the second example stated above is compiled as follows (a[k1][]->k2->k3[k4] = x):
PhpArray a1,a2; DObject o1,o2; a1 = Operators.EnsureVariableIsArray(ref a); if (a1 == null) goto end; a1 = Operators.EnsureItemIsArray(a1,k1); if (a1 == null) goto end; a1.Add(o2 = stdClass.CreateDefaultObject(context)); o1 = Operators.EnsurePropertyIsObject(o2,k2,context); if (o1 == null) goto end; a2 = Operators.EnsurePropertyIsArray(o1,k3); if (a2 == null) goto end; Operators.SetArrayItem(a2,k4,PhpVariable.Copy(x,CopyReason.Assignment)); end:
The chain in the third example stated above is compiled as follows (A::$x[k1]->f(arg)->x =& x, assuming declaration function& f($a) {...} for example):
// the first subchain: PhpArray a1; DObject o1; a1 = Operators.EnsureStaticPropertyIsArray("A","x",type_handle,context); if (a1 == null) goto end; o1 = a1.EnsureItemIsObject(k1,context); if (o1 == null) goto end;
// an ordinary PHP method call: PhpReference r1; context.Stack.AddFrame(arg); r1 = Operators.InvokeMethod(o1,"f",type_handle);
// the second subchain: DObject o2; o2 = Operators.EnsureVariableIsObject(ref r1.value,context); if (o2 == null) goto end; Operators.SetObjectProperty(o2,"x",x,type_handle); end:
Array construction
The array keyword is used to create a new instance of PHP array (). It takes a sequence of key-value pairs and/or single values. Both keys and values can be expressions. Moreover, a value can be preceded by the reference modifier (&) allowing values to be added to the resulting array as references.
The array construct is implemented by construction a new a in which entries are added as described in the following table.
Array construction elementImplementation
x => y(a,x,PhpVariable.(y,CopyReason.))
x =>& p(a,x,p)
xa.(PhpVariable.(x,CopyReason.))
List language construct
The list language construct is a shorthand for several assignments of array items. It can be used only on the left hand side of the = operator. Statement list(<rw_expr_1>,...,<rw_expr_k>) = <expression> is implemented as a sequence of and PHP assignments if the rhs is an array (see operators = on variable, array item and object property in tables above). Otherwise, a null reference is assigned to each expression on the lhs. Sequence is in reverse order then it is stated in the list "arguments", i.e. the first item assigned is the last one in the list. Right hand side expression is evaluated once before assignments take place.
Indirect variable accessImplementation
$$x(variables_table,x)
$$x = y(variables_table,x,PhpVariable.(y,CopyReason.))
$$x =& p(variables_table,x,p)
p =& $$xp = (variables_table,x)
isset($$x)(variables_table,x) != null
unset($$x)variables_table.(x)

member.remarks: A variable is considered to be empty for ensure routines and item and property operators if it is either null reference, an empty string, an empty string of bytes, false, 0 or 0.0 (PHP5 treats 0 and 0.0 as non-empty-for-ensure but it will probably change).

member.returns: true if denotes a function, false otherwise.

item.description: The is converted to an integer by . If the result of the conversion is negative or points beyond the last character/byte of the the null is returned (this is slightly different behavior from the PHP but more consistent paying attention to the "isset" PHP function implementation). Otherwise, the -th character and byte is wrapped into a new string and instance, respectively, and returned.
The value associated with is returned.
It is a fatal error to apply the operator to an instance of .

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpArray.CompareTo(System.Object,System.Collections.IComparer)
member.summary: Compares this instance with an object of arbitrary PHP.NET type.

remarks.para: Empty array is equal to the null reference.
Non empty array is greater than the null reference.
If is of type then the comparison is performed between the boolean term "the number of items in this instance is positive" and .

If is of type then the item counts are compared at first, the corresponding keys then and finally the corresponding values are compared. Values comparison is performed by specified and can be recursive. Never-ending recursion is prevented.

member.param: An object to compare with this instance.
A comparer to be used for comparing items contained in this instance.
member.returns: Negative integer if this instance is less than , zero if this instance equals to and positive integer if this instance is greater than .
member.remarks: The is used to compare items which contained in this instance (useful when the instance is an array or object etc.).

member.summary: Compares two instances of .
member.param: Whether arrays are incomparable (no difference is found before both arrays enters an infinite recursion). Returns zero then.
member.returns: Negative integer if is less than , zero if equals to and positive integer if is greater than .

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpArray.StrictCompareEq(PHP.Core.PhpArray)
member.summary: Compares this instance with another .
member.param: The array to be strictly compared.
member.returns: Whether this instance strictly equals to .
member.remarks: Arrays are strictly equal if all entries are strictly equal and in the same order in both arrays. Entries are strictly equal if keys are the same and values are strictly equal in the terms of operator .

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpObject.#ctor(PHP.Core.ScriptContext,PHP.Core.Reflection.DTypeDesc)
member.summary: Creates a new PhpObject and calls its PHP constructors (__construct or PHP 4 style constructor).
member.param: The to create the instance with.
of the object that requests the construction.

remarks.para: This constructor should be used when instantiating PHP classes by the Phalanger compiler. Derived classes must also contain a constructor with this signature.

In fact, this very constructor will never be called and is included here just to show how constructors with this signature whould work in derived classes. Firstly, the constructor of the same class is invoked in order to initialize all fields along the inheritance hierarchy. Then the method is called in order to locate and invoke a PHP constructor. There is no base(context, callingTypeHandle) upcall, in particular.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpObject.#ctor(PHP.Core.ScriptContext,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new PhpObject without calling its PHP constructor.
member.param: The to create the instance with.
Determines whether this instance was created using the new construct (true), or just as a clone of another instance (false).
member.remarks: This constructor is used when PHP constructors must not be called - when cloning s ( is false) and when the caller is going to invoke a PHP constructor ( is true). Derived classes must also contain a constructor with this signature.

member.summary: Notifies derived classes that this instance has just been created.
member.remarks: Called before __construct is invoked. When overriding, make sure you call the overriden method (base.InstanceCreated(context)).

member.name: T:PHP.Core.PhpRuntimeChain
member.summary: Represents an operator chain at runtime.
member.remarks: When a compile-time unknown function invocation is encountered and it has a complex parameter consisting of an operator chain, evaluation of the chain must be postponed to run-time. Only at run-time it becomes clear whether the chain's outcome should be an object or a (formal parameter equipped with the &) which leads to somewhat different evaluation procedure.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.PhpStack
member.summary: A stack used to perform indirect calls of user funcions and to call argument-aware functions.

remarks.para: A stack is used for calling m-decl and args-aware PHP functions/methods. 1. Caller of such function pushes all arguments into this stack, sets ArgCount to the argument count pushed and calls argument-less overload. If a method is called a caller invokes Operators.InvokeMethod method and this one calls argument-less overload. 2. Argument-less overload reads ArgCount arguments from the stack, pushes them to the evalution stack and calls argument-full overload. If the callee is args-aware function/method arguments are kept on the stack until callee returns and are popped afterwards. Moreover, the number of arguments is boxed and pushed on the top of the stack in order to be used by class library funcions working with arguments (such are func_get_args etc.). Otherwise, if the function/method is args-unaware, stack frame is deleted before the function/method is called.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpStack.MakeArgsAware(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the stack up so it is prepared for the arg-full overload call. Called in args-aware stubs after peeking all arguments and before calling the arg-full overload.
member.returns: The number of arguments pushed on the stack.
member.remarks: An args-aware stub is usually called when the caller doesn't know which arguments are references and which not. Therefore, the stub should dereference all that arguments which are not references. Those arguments on the stack corresponding with formal ones are dereferenced by and methods. Others are dereferenced here.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.PhpArrayString
member.summary: Created by ensuring operators (i.e. when a chain is written) if the ensured value is a non-empty string. Holds a string container ( or ). The operator immediately following the ensuring operator either raises an error if it is an ensuring operator or modifies byte/character in the string if it is a operator.

member.summary: Emits the call of DRoutine.
member.param: Fallback function name to call, if the origin one does not exist.
IPlace containing instance of object in case of non static method call.
True to check visibility during runtime.
The index of overload (used in case of PhpLibraryFunction).
Type used to resolve this routine.
Access type of the routine call. Used to determine wheter the caller does not need return value. In such case additional operations (like CastToFalse) should not be emitted.
True to call the instance method virtually, using .callvirt instruction. This is used when current routine is non-static routine called on instance, not statically.

member.summary: Used to merge namespaces included by the caller of 'eval' function.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Reflection.SourceUnit.ResolveName(PHP.Core.QualifiedName,PHP.Core.Reflection.DeclarationKind,PHP.Core.Reflection.Scope,System.Nullable{PHP.Core.QualifiedName}@,PHP.Core.ErrorSink,PHP.Core.Parsers.Position,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Resolves a function or type name using aliases and imported namespaces of the source unit.
member.param: Function qualified name to resolve. Doesn't resolve special names ("self", "parent").
null, if the function name is resolved immediately. Otherwise, if the is simple and an alias exists, contains its qualified target.
Error sink or null if errors shouldn't be reported.
Position where to report an error.
Whether name must be resolved if possible.
member.returns: Resolved member, the unknown member, or null if error reporting is disabled (errors == null).
member.remarks: If the name is simple, is not resolved and has an alias then the run-time resolve should be run on the alias. If the name is simple, is not resolved and hasn't an alias, the run-time resolve should be run on the name within the naming context of the source unit (i.e. imported namespaces should be considered). If the name is fully qualified and is not resolved then then the run-time resolve should be run on the name itself.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Reflection.DType.AnalyzeInheritance(PHP.Core.ErrorSink)
member.summary: Analyzes inheritance properties of the PHP types and constructed types being declared in the current compilation. The properties being analyzed primarily include the definiteness of the type.

remarks.para: The constructed types themselves can't get the analysis into a loop as they form a DAG structure (grammar defines a tree structure and unifying the same constructed types results in the DAG). However, the completeness of a constructed type depends on the completeness of the components - the generic type and all the type arguments. Since a polymorphic recursion can take place (e.g. B{T} extends A{B{T}}), we need to employ minimal fixpoint algorithm to determine the type completeness.

If is non-negative the method performs DFS on the graph of PHP types and constructed types, going to the depth recursively adding the type being analyzed to the if it closes a loop. It also adds the into its list of DFS predecessors (if non-null). The tracks the last DFS predecessor that was PhpType (not constructed).

Terminology: - "inheritance edge" is an edge going from a type to its immediate base type (class or interface) - "constructed edge" is an edge going from a constructed type to a generic argument - "generic edge" is an edge going from a constructed type to the generic type

During the DFS, records the current depth in the DFS tree. records the length of a path from the current type to the first node of a constructed edge (the path therefore comprises of inheritance and generic edges).
The DFS depth is stored on PhpTypes and is used to discover circular inheriting among inherited types. When a backward edge is discovered and the target type (which must be either a PhpType or a ConstructedType, considering the generic type in the latter case) the DFS depth difference between the target type and the current type is calculated. If it is less than the current inheritance depth then there is a loop comprising of inheritance edges only (which is an error).
NOTE: It suffice to store the DFS depth only on PhpTypes (in ). Depth comparison in constructed type compares the inheritance depth of the generic type with the difference of the DFS depths minus one -- as if the backward edge pointed directly to the generic type.
If is -1 the method only updates the properties whose procesing requires MFP and adds the types listed in the DFS predecessors list to the worklist if any of these properties changed.
The lists of DFS predecessors are cleaned up later during the DType clean-up (TODO: clean the builders as well).

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Reflection.DType.ResolveAbstractOverrides(PHP.Core.ErrorSink)
member.summary: For each method M, finds out the method that is overridden by the method M as well as all interface methods that are implemented by the method M.
member.remarks: Must be called after member-analysis as all types and their members have to be known. Assumes that the inheritance hierarchy is free of circular dependencies.
member.param: Error sink, can be null is you don't care.

Whether the analyzer can be sure about the identity of the type. A type is error definite if it is a unconditionally declared type or if it is a reflected type.
Note that reflected types are resolved iff they are active at the time of the resolving. A reflected type declared unconditionally in its compilation unit is active since the module is loaded (the module's auto-reflection code declares it on ). A reflected type declared conditionally is activated by a call to the .

Ghost implementations are stubs that are required to be added to the class in order to tackle CLR inability to bind abstract method/property defined in interface I with its implementation defined in a superclass B of the class A implementing the interface. member.name: T:PHP.Core.RequestContext
member.summary: Represents a set of data associated with the current web request targeting PHP scripts.
Represents a set of data associated with the current web request targeting PHP scripts.

member.summary: Initializes the context.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.RequestContext.Initialize(PHP.Core.ApplicationContext,System.Web.HttpContext)
member.summary: Creates and initializes request and script contexts associated with the current thread.
member.returns: The initialized request context.

remarks.para: Request context provides PHP with the web server environment. It should be initialized before any PHP code is invoked within web server and finalized (disposed) at the end of the request. This method can be called for multiple times, however it creates and initializes a new request context only once per HTTP request.

The following steps take place during the initialization (in this order):
Configuration is loaded (if not loaded yet). A new instance of is created and bound to the current thread. A new instance of is created and initialized. Event is fired. Session is started if session auto-start confgiuration option is switched on.
The request context can be accessed via the returned instance or via thread static field anytime between the initialization and disposal.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.RequestContext.FinalizeContext

member.summary: Adds/update a SID global PHP constant.
member.remarks: The constant is non-empty only for cookie-less sessions.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.RequestContext.StartSession
member.summary: Starts session if not already started. Loads session variables from HttpContext.Session.
member.para: Session state (HttpContext.Session) has to be available at the time of the call. Otherwise, an exception occurs.

Starting the session inheres in importing session variables from the session data store. The store is specific to the current PHP session handler defined by configuration option . In the case the ASP.NET handler is active, values from HttpContext.Session are imported to $_SESSION PHP auto-global variable. Hence, items added to the HttpContext.Session by non-PHP code after the start of the session will not be visible to PHP code. The $_SESSION variable has to be updated directly (see ScriptContext.AutoGlobals) to make these items visible to PHP.
member.exception: Session state not available.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.RequestContext.EndSession(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Ends session, i.e. stores content of the $_SESSION array to the HttpContext.Session collection.
member.param: Whether to abandon the session without persisting variables.
member.exception: Session state not available.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.RequestContext.Dispose
member.summary: Finalizes (disposes) the request context.
member.remarks:
Finalization comprises of the following actions (executed in the order):
Output buffers are flushed. This action may include calls to user defined filters (see ob_start function). Shutdown callbacks are invoked (if added by register_shutdown_function function). Session is closed. User defined session handling function may be invoked (see session_set_save_handler function). PHP objects are destroyed. HTTP Headers are flushed (if it wasn't done earlier). PHP resources are disposed. Per-request temporary files are deleted. event is fired. Current request and script contexts are nulled.
Multiple invocations of the method are ignored. Since session data need to be written to the session store (HttpContext.Session) this method has to be called before the ASP.NET session is ended for the request.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.ScriptContext.InitApplication(PHP.Core.ApplicationContext,System.Type,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes the script context for a PHP console application.
member.param: The main script's type or a null reference for a pure application.
A path to the main script source file.
A source root within which an application has been compiler.
member.returns: A new instance of with its own copy of local configuration to be used by the application.
member.exception: Web configuration is invalid. The context is not initialized then.
member.remarks:
Use this method if you want to initialize application in the same way the PHP console/Windows application is initialized. The returned script context is initialized as follows:
The application's source root is set. The main script of the application is defined. Output and input streams are set to standard output and input, respectively. Current culture it set to . Auto-global variables ($_GET, $_SET, etc.) are initialized. Working directory is set tothe current working directory.

member.name: F:PHP.Core.ScriptContext.setterChainStack
member.summary: A stack of s that are currently being processed.

remarks.para: s are maintained in a stack in order to support nested operator chains.
Every time the or is called on a system class with overloaded member access (__set and/or __get), a new is pushed to the stack ().

If a setter chain has been created, the consequent chaining operators just record field and item names to it (). The last operator calls which causes the recorded data to be passed to the __set handler and the popped from the stack.

member.param: The setter chain element to add.

member.summary: Pops the current setter chain without invoking the setter.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.ScriptContext.FinishSetterChain(System.Object)
member.summary: Passes the current setter chain to the setter and pops the setter chain. Called from chaining operators that conclude the chain that might contain or when they detect they are part of a setter chain.
member.param: The value that should be assigned to the field/item represented by the last setter chain element.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.Deserializer.WrapPropertyValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Wraps a with a non-aliased to allow for reference fix-ups after deserialization.
member.returns: to if is a , or itself otherwise.

remarks.para: The purpose of this wrapping is to avoid s referencing another s directly which causes problems when such an object graph is deserialized.

Without this wrapping, under certain circumstances serialization would fail with the following exception message: The object with ID 5 implements the interface for which all dependencies cannot be resolved. The likely cause is two instances of that have a mutual dependency on each other.

member.name: T:PHP.Library.SPL.Serializable
member.summary: Interface for customized serializing.
member.remarks: Classes that implement this interface no longer support __sleep and __wakeup. The method serialize is called whenever an instance needs to be serialized. This does not invoke __destruct or has any other side effect unless programmed inside the method. When the data is unserialized the class is known and the appropriate unserialize method is called as a constructor instead of calling __construct. If you need to execute the standard constructor you may do so in the method.

member.name: M:PHP.Library.SPL.Serializable.serialize(PHP.Core.ScriptContext)
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the instance or null.

member.name: M:PHP.Library.SPL.Serializable.unserialize(PHP.Core.ScriptContext,System.Object)
member.summary: Reconstructs the instance from a string representation passed as the only parameter.

member.name: M:PHP.Library.SPL.ArrayObject.asort(PHP.Core.ScriptContext)
member.summary: Sorts the entries such that the keys maintain their correlation with the entries they are associated with. This is used mainly when sorting associative arrays where the actual element order is significant.

member.name: M:PHP.Library.SPL.ArrayObject.ksort(PHP.Core.ScriptContext)
member.summary: Sorts the entries by key, maintaining key to entry correlations. This is useful mainly for associative arrays.

member.name: M:PHP.Library.SPL.ArrayObject.natcasesort(PHP.Core.ScriptContext)
member.summary: This method is a case insensitive version of ArrayObject::natsort. This method implements a sort algorithm that orders alphanumeric strings in the way a human being would while maintaining key/value associations. This is described as a "natural ordering".

member.name: M:PHP.Library.SPL.ArrayObject.natsort(PHP.Core.ScriptContext)
member.summary: This method implements a sort algorithm that orders alphanumeric strings in the way a human being would while maintaining key/value associations. This is described as a "natural ordering". An example of the difference between this algorithm and the regular computer string sorting algorithms (used in ArrayObject::asort) method can be seen in the example below.

member.name: M:PHP.Library.SPL.ArrayObject.uasort(PHP.Core.ScriptContext,System.Object)
member.summary: This function sorts the entries such that keys maintain their correlation with the entry that they are associated with, using a user-defined comparison function. This is used mainly when sorting associative arrays where the actual element order is significant.
member.param: Function cmp_function should accept two parameters which will be filled by pairs of entries. The comparison function must return an integer less than, equal to, or greater than zero if the first argument is considered to be respectively less than, equal to, or greater than the second.

member.name: M:PHP.Library.SPL.ArrayObject.uksort(PHP.Core.ScriptContext,System.Object)
member.summary: This function sorts the keys of the entries using a user-supplied comparison function. The key to entry correlations will be maintained.
member.param: The callback comparison function. Function cmp_function should accept two parameters which will be filled by pairs of entry keys. The comparison function must return an integer less than, equal to, or greater than zero if the first argument is considered to be respectively less than, equal to, or greater than the second.

member.name: T:PHP.Library.SPL.ArrayIterator
member.summary:
This iterator allows to unset and modify values and keys while iterating over Arrays and Objects.
When you want to iterate over the same array multiple times you need to instantiate ArrayObject and let it create ArrayIterator instances that refer to it either by using foreach or by calling its getIterator() method manually.

member.name: T:PHP.Library.SPL.IteratorIterator
member.summary: This iterator wrapper allows the conversion of anything that is Traversable into an Iterator. It is important to understand that most classes that do not implement Iterators have reasons as most likely they do not allow the full Iterator feature set. If so, techniques should be provided to prevent misuse, otherwise expect exceptions or fatal errors.

member.summary: Creates a stack trace containing only those frames visible to PHP code.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpStackTrace.TraceErrorFrame(PHP.Core.ScriptContext)
member.summary: Traces up the stack frame containing the method call that has caused an error.
member.returns: Found stack info.
member.remarks: Starts with a frame of a calling method and ends with the first frame belonging to user routine. If there was found during the walk the last one's value is considered as the caller. If there was not such attribute found (error occured in an operator, directly in the code etc.) the last inspected method's debug info is returned. If the trace ends up with a function or method inside transient assembly an eval hierarchy is inspected and added to the resulting source position information.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpStackTrace.FillEvalStackInfo(PHP.Core.ScriptContext,System.Int32,PHP.Core.ErrorStackInfo@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Fills an instance of with information gathered from eval transient debug info.
member.param: An id of the inner-most eval where an error occured.
Whether the message is used in HTML.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpStackTrace.HideTransparentEvals(System.Collections.Generic.List{PHP.Core.ErrorStackInfo})
member.summary: Modifies a specified eval trace such that all transparent evals get hidden. The others will have updated line numbers.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpStackTrace.EvalTraceToFileName(System.Collections.Generic.List{PHP.Core.ErrorStackInfo},System.String,System.Boolean)
M:PHP.Core.PhpStackTrace.GetClassContext
member.summary: Traces the calling stack to discover current PHP class context.
member.returns: of the PHP class that represents current class context for this thread or null if this thread is executing in a function or startup Main context.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpStackTrace.GetUserTrace
member.summary: Returns array containing current stack state. Each item is an array representing one stack frame.
member.returns: The stack trace.
member.remarks:
The resulting array contains the following items (their keys are stated):
"file" - a source file where the function/method has been called
"line" - a line in a source code where the function/method has been called
"column" - a column in a source code where the function/method has been called
"function" - a name of the function/method
"class" - a name of a class where the method is declared (if any)
"type" - either "::" for static methods or "->" for instance methods
Unsupported items:
"args" - routine arguments
"object" - target instance of the method invocation

member.name: M:PHP.Core.PhpStackTrace.FormatUserTrace(PHP.Core.PhpArray)
member.summary: Formats a trace to user string.
member.param: An array containing the user trace.
member.returns: The formatted trace.

member.summary: Formats a trace to user string.
member.returns: The formatted trace.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.StreamWrapper
member.summary: Abstract base class for PHP stream wrappers. Descendants define methods implementing fopen, stat, unlink, rename, opendir, mkdir and rmdir for different stream types.
Abstract base class for PHP stream wrappers. Descendants define methods implementing fopen, stat, unlink, rename, opendir, mkdir and rmdir for different stream types.
member.remarks:
Each script has its own copy of registeredWrappers stored in the ScriptContext.
PhpStream is created by a StreamWrapper on a call to fopen(). Wrappers are stateless: they provide an instance of PhpStream on fopen() and an instance of DirectoryListing on opendir().

member.name: M:PHP.Core.StreamWrapper.Stat(System.String,PHP.Core.StreamStatOptions,PHP.Core.StreamContext,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates the stat-structure for a specified file.
member.remarks: Regarding the stream_wrapper_register(), the stat() is an instance method of a stream. Maybe a PhpStream should remember the open-path of the contained file for such purposes but currently I can see no PHP function requiring stat() on an opened stream.
member.param: Wheter to use stream_stat() or url_stat() when invoking user wrapper.
member.returns: A containing the stat information about the target file or with st_size set to -1 in case of failure.
member.exception: Throws a warning in case of failure.
member.remarks: for the list of additional options.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.StreamWrapper.Open(System.String@,System.String,PHP.Core.StreamOpenOptions,PHP.Core.StreamContext)
member.summary: Called by fopen() for the specific wrapper determined by the scheme portion of an URL. Override in descendants to make new instances of s.
member.param: The path passed to fopen() which will be set to the opened absolute path.
The context provided for the stream wrapper at the call to fopen().
member.returns: A new instance of encapsulating the data Stream. Returns null in case of failure - will be cast to false for fopen().

member.name: T:PHP.Core.FileStreamWrapper
member.summary: Derived from , this class provides access to the local filesystem files.
Derived from , this class provides access to the local filesystem files.
member.remarks:
The virtual working directory is handled by the PhpPath class in the Class Library. The absolute path resolution (using the working diretory and the include_path if necessary) and open-basedir check is performed by the method.
This wrapper expects the path to be an absolute local filesystem path without the file:// scheme specifier.

member.summary: Creates a from the filling the common members (for files and directories) from the given class. The size member (numeric index 7) may be filled by the caller for when is a .
member.remarks:
According to these outputs (PHP Win32):
fstat(somefile.txt): [dev] => 0 [ino] => 0 [mode] => 33206 [nlink] => 1 [uid] => 0 [gid] => 0 [rdev] => 0 [size] => 24 [atime] => 1091131360 [mtime] => 1091051699 [ctime] => 1091051677 [blksize] => -1 [blocks] => -1
stat(somefile.txt): [dev] => 2 [ino] => 0 [mode] => 33206 // 0100666 [nlink] => 1 [uid] => 0 [gid] => 0 [rdev] => 2 [size] => 24 [atime] => 1091129621 [mtime] => 1091051699 [ctime] => 1091051677 [blksize] => -1 [blocks] => -1
stat(somedir): [st_dev] => 2 [st_ino] => 0 [st_mode] => 16895 // 040777 [st_nlink] => 1 [st_uid] => 0 [st_gid] => 0 [st_rdev] => 2 [st_size] => 0 [st_atime] => 1091109319 [st_mtime] => 1091044521 [st_ctime] => 1091044521 [st_blksize] => -1 [st_blocks] => -1
member.param: A or of the stat()ed filesystem entry.
The path to the file / directory.
member.returns: A for use in the stat() related functions.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.InputOutputStreamWrapper.In
member.summary: Represents the console input stream (alias php://stdin).
member.remarks: It is a persistent text stream. This means that it is never closed by fclose() and \r\n is converted to \n.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.InputOutputStreamWrapper.Out
member.summary: Represents the console output stream (alias php://stdout).
member.remarks: It is a persistent text stream. This means that it is never closed by fclose() and \n is converted to \r\n.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.InputOutputStreamWrapper.Error
member.summary: Represents the console error stream (alias php://error).
member.remarks: It is a persistent text stream. This means that it is never closed by fclose() and \n is converted to \r\n.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.InputOutputStreamWrapper.ScriptInput
member.summary: Represents the script input stream (containing the raw POST data).
member.remarks: It is a persistent binary stream. This means that it is never closed by fclose() and no EOLN mapping is performed.

member.name: P:PHP.Core.InputOutputStreamWrapper.ScriptOutput
member.summary: Represents the script output stream (alias php://output).
member.remarks: It is a persistent binary stream. This means that it is never closed by fclose() and no EOLN mapping is performed.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions
member.summary: Flags returned by indicating additional information to the parsed and .

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions.Empty
member.summary: Empty (invalid) value (0).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions.Read
member.summary: The stream was opened for reading (1).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions.Write
member.summary: The stream was opened for writing (2).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions.UseText
member.summary: Use text access to the stream (default is binary) (4).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions.SeekEnd
member.summary: Seek to the end of the stream is required (8).
member.remarks: The given mode requires "a+", which is not supported by .NET Framework; mode is reset to "r+" and a seek is required.

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions.Exclusive
member.summary: The mode starts with 'x' which requires a Warning if the file already exists. It is not applicable to remote files (16).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions.FindFile
member.summary: This file may be searched in the include_path if requested (only the modes opening existing files) (32).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions.Temporary
member.summary: When a local file is opened using tmpfile() it should be removed when closed (256).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamAccessOptions.Persistent
member.summary: Denotes a persistent version of the stream (2048).

member.name: T:PHP.Core.StreamOptions
member.summary: Flags passed in the options argument to the method.

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.Empty
member.summary: Empty option (default)

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.UseIncludePath
member.summary: If path is relative, Wrapper will search for the resource using the include_path (1).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.IgnoreUrl
member.summary: When this flag is set, only the file:// wrapper is considered. (2)

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.EnforceSafeMode
member.summary: Apply the safe_mode permissions check when opening a file (4).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.ReportErrors
member.summary: If this flag is set, the Wrapper is responsible for raising errors using trigger_error() during opening of the stream. If this flag is not set, she should not raise any errors (8).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.MustSeek
member.summary: If you don't need to write to the stream, but really need to be able to seek, use this flag in your options (16).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.WillCast
member.summary: If you are going to end up casting the stream into a FILE* or a socket, pass this flag and the streams/wrappers will not use buffering mechanisms while reading the headers, so that HTTP wrapped streams will work consistently. If you omit this flag, streams will use buffering and should end up working more optimally (32).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.LocateWrappersOnly
member.summary: This flag applies to php_stream_locate_url_wrapper (64).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.OpenForInclude
member.summary: This flag is only used by include/require functions (128).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.UseUrl
member.summary: This flag tells streams to ONLY open urls (256).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.OnlyGetHeaders
member.summary: This flag is used when only the headers from HTTP request are to be fetched (512).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.DisableOpenBasedir
member.summary: Don't apply open_basedir checks (1024).

member.name: F:PHP.Core.StreamOptions.Persistent
member.summary: Get (or create) a persistent version of the stream (2048).

member.name: T:PHP.Core.StringUtils
member.summary: Utilities manipulating strings.

member.name: M:PHP.Core.StringUtils.Increment(System.String)
member.summary: Increments a string in a manner of Perl (and also PHP).
member.returns: The incremented string.

remarks.para: Single characters are incremented such that '0' changes to '1', ..., '8' to '9' and '9' to '0' with a carry, 'a' changes to 'b', ..., 'z' to 'a' (with a carry) and finally 'A' to 'B', ..., 'Z' to 'A' (with a carry). Other characters remain unchanged and generate no carry.

Characters of the string are incremented starting from the last one advancing to the beginning of the string and ending when there is no carry generated or no character available (i.e. we proceeded the first character of the string). In latter case appropriate character ('1', 'a' or 'A') is prepended before the result.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.WeakCache`1
member.summary: Maps real objects to their associates (of type ).
member.typeparam: The type of objects associated with real objects.
member.remarks: The cache should store only the real objects that are alive, i.e. reachable from GC roots. It is assumed that there exists a (strong) reference from instances of to their associated real objects. Therefore holding the associates in this cache using strong references only would not work and a more sophisticated pattern is employed.

member.summary: Removes items representing real objects that are already dead.

member.summary: Ensures that the associate of the given real object is held strongly.
member.remarks: Should be called from within the associate's finalizer when the real object is figured out to be still alive.

member.name: T:PHP.Core.WeakCache`1.WeakCacheKey
member.summary: Weak reference with overriden and .
